arguments.argument: The filibuster obstructs majority rule and democratic decision-making.
It leads to legislative gridlock and prevents necessary reforms.
The filibuster was historically used to block civil rights legislation.
It gives too much power to the minority party to obstruct governance.
Eliminating it would ensure a more efficient legislative process.
It prevents Congress from responding quickly to urgent issues.
The filibuster has been increasingly abused for partisan purposes.
Many state legislatures operate effectively without a filibuster.
It was not originally part of the Constitution and is an outdated rule.
Eliminating it would increase government accountability and responsiveness.
The filibuster protects minority party rights in the Senate.
It ensures that major laws require broad bipartisan support.
Removing it could lead to frequent and extreme policy changes.
The filibuster encourages compromise and debate.
Without it, the Senate could pass laws too hastily.
The filibuster serves as a check on the power of the ruling party.
Both parties have used the filibuster to block harmful legislation.
Eliminating it could make the Senate function like the House of Representatives.
It helps maintain long-term stability in U.S. policies.
Modifying rather than eliminating the filibuster would be a better solution.
